scenario: People who drink green tea daily report lower stress levels.
claim: Green tea reduces stress.
label: NO
causal_structure: Health-conscious individuals both drink green tea and manage stress better.
key_insight: Lifestyle confounding explains the association.
hidden_timestamp: Were stress levels lower before green tea habits formed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If stress was already low before green tea, the relationship is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stress dropped only after starting tea, a causal effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: We cannot conclude causation because stress differences may reflect pre-existing lifestyle differences.
gold_rationale: Health-conscious individuals cause both green tea consumption and lower stress.

scenario: People who own fitness trackers have lower resting heart rates.
claim: Fitness trackers improve heart health.
label: NO
causal_structure: People already committed to fitness buy trackers and also have better heart health.
key_insight: Pre-existing fitness confounds the relationship.
hidden_timestamp: Did fitness habits start before or after buying the tracker?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If habits predate the tracker, no causal effect is shown.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If heart rate improved only after tracker use, effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Tracker ownership may just signal existing healthy behavior.
gold_rationale: Fitness habits drive both tracker ownership and heart rate.

scenario: People who use blackout curtains report better sleep quality.
claim: Blackout curtains improve sleep.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: Curtains may help, but other environmental factors also affect sleep.
key_insight: Multiple environmental confounders.
hidden_timestamp: Did sleep improve immediately after curtain installation?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sleep improved right after installation, a causal link is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If other lifestyle changes occurred, causation is unclear.

wise_refusal: Sleep changes may reflect multiple environmental or behavioral factors.
gold_rationale: Curtains might help, but noise or schedule confounders exist.

scenario: People who take multivitamins report fewer colds.
claim: Multivitamins prevent colds.
label: NO
causal_structure: Health-conscious individuals take vitamins and also avoid illness.
key_insight: Healthy user bias.
hidden_timestamp: Were vitamin users already healthier?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If users were already healthier, effect is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If illness dropped only after starting vitamins, effect is plausible.

wise_refusal: Vitamin use may signal broader healthy behaviors.
gold_rationale: Health behavior confounds the relationship.

scenario: Employees who work from home report higher productivity.
claim: Working from home increases productivity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Jobs suitable for remote work differ systematically.
key_insight: Selection bias in job types.
hidden_timestamp: Were these workers already in higher-autonomy roles?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only certain job types went remote, the effect is selection bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the same roles switched to remote and improved, effect is plausible.

wise_refusal: Remote work effects may reflect job selection rather than causation.
gold_rationale: Job type confounds productivity differences.

scenario: Students who sit in the front row get higher grades.
claim: Sitting in the front row improves academic performance.
label: NO
causal_structure: More motivated students choose front seats and also perform better.
key_insight: Motivation drives both seating choice and grades.
hidden_timestamp: Were these students already high achievers before choosing seats?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If they were already strong students, seating is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If grades improved after moving seats, a causal effect is possible.

wise_refusal: Seating may reflect motivation rather than cause performance.
gold_rationale: Motivation confounds the association.

scenario: Dog owners walk more steps per day than non-dog owners.
claim: Owning a dog increases daily exercise.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: Active people may be more likely to own dogs.
key_insight: Direction of causality unclear.
hidden_timestamp: Did exercise levels change after adopting the dog?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If exercise increased after adoption, effect is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If owners were already active, no causal effect is shown.

wise_refusal: Dog ownership may reflect pre-existing activity preferences.
gold_rationale: Lifestyle preference confounds the relationship.

scenario: People who listen to classical music score higher on IQ tests.
claim: Classical music increases intelligence.
label: NO
causal_structure: Higher socioeconomic status leads to both classical music exposure and higher test scores.
key_insight: SES confounds the relationship.
hidden_timestamp: Did IQ scores rise after starting classical music exposure?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If SES explains both, music is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If IQ improved only after exposure, effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Music preference may reflect socioeconomic background.
gold_rationale: SES drives both variables.

scenario: Ice cream sales rise on days with more drownings.
claim: Eating ice cream causes drowning.
label: NO
causal_structure: Hot weather increases both swimming and ice cream consumption.
key_insight: Common cause confounding.
hidden_timestamp: Were drownings higher on hot days regardless of ice cream?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If drownings correlate with heat not ice cream, no causation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If drownings occur independent of weather, effect is unclear.

wise_refusal: The correlation is explained by hot weather.
gold_rationale: Weather is the confounder.

scenario: People who sleep 8 hours perform better at work.
claim: Sleeping 8 hours increases productivity.
label: YES
causal_structure: Participants were randomly assigned to sleep duration groups.
key_insight: Random assignment supports causality.
hidden_timestamp: Were participants randomly assigned sleep schedules?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If assignment was random, the causal claim is valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If sleep duration was self-selected, confounding remains.

wise_refusal: If sleep duration was randomized, the evidence supports a causal claim.
gold_rationale: Randomization eliminates confounding.

scenario: People who eat breakfast every day report having more energy throughout the morning.
claim: Eating breakfast increases morning energy.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: Energy may depend on sleep and diet quality, which also correlate with breakfast habits.
key_insight: Breakfast effect is plausible but not isolated.
hidden_timestamp: Did energy improve after starting a consistent breakfast routine, holding sleep constant?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sleep and diet stayed the same and energy increased after breakfast, causality is plausible.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If breakfast coincided with better sleep/diet, the relationship is confounded.

wise_refusal: Without controlling for sleep and overall diet, we cannot attribute energy changes to breakfast alone.
gold_rationale: The association could be causal, but confounding from sleep and diet quality makes it uncertain.

scenario: Drivers who take a defensive driving course have fewer accidents in the following year than drivers who do not.
claim: Defensive driving courses reduce accidents.
label: YES
causal_structure: A lottery among oversubscribed applicants quasi-randomly assigns course access, reducing confounding.
key_insight: Quasi-random assignment supports causality.
hidden_timestamp: Was course participation determined by a lottery among similar applicants?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If assignment was lottery-based, the causal claim is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If safer drivers self-selected into the course, the association is confounded.

wise_refusal: If access was quasi-random (lottery), it supports a causal effect; otherwise selection bias may explain it.
gold_rationale: Lottery assignment approximates randomization, making accident differences attributable to the course.

scenario: People who delete Instagram report feeling less anxious one month later.
claim: Deleting Instagram reduces anxiety.
label: NO
causal_structure: People may delete Instagram during a peak anxiety period; anxiety may naturally decline afterward regardless.
key_insight: A temporary spike can create a misleading “improvement” effect.
hidden_timestamp: Did people delete Instagram specifically after an unusually anxious week?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If deletion followed an anxiety peak, the drop may be regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If deletion timing was unrelated to anxiety peaks and anxiety decreased, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If deletion happens during anxiety peaks, later improvement may reflect regression to the mean rather than a causal effect.
gold_rationale: Selection into deletion at extreme anxiety values can produce apparent improvement without causation.

scenario: People who use budgeting apps have higher savings balances than people who do not.
claim: Budgeting apps increase savings.
label: NO
causal_structure: More financially disciplined or higher-income individuals adopt apps and also save more.
key_insight: Self-selection drives the association.
hidden_timestamp: Were users already saving more before they started using the app?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If they were already saving more, the relationship is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If savings increased only after app adoption with stable income, a causal effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: App use may reflect pre-existing discipline or income differences rather than causing higher savings.
gold_rationale: Discipline/income (Z) influences both app adoption (X) and savings (Y).

scenario: A university unexpectedly changed its library hours from 10pm to 2am during finals week for staffing reasons, while a similar university nearby did not. Students at the first university studied longer on average and had slightly higher final exam scores.
claim: Extending library hours increases exam performance.
label: YES
causal_structure: An exogenous policy change provides a comparison between affected and unaffected students.
key_insight: Exogenous shock + comparison group supports causality.
hidden_timestamp: Was the change unrelated to student performance trends and only due to staffing?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the hours change was exogenous and the campuses were comparable, the causal claim is supported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the change happened because of performance issues or other concurrent interventions, confounding remains.

wise_refusal: If the policy change was truly exogenous and there is a valid comparison group, the evidence supports causality.
gold_rationale: The unexpected hours extension acts like a natural experiment, reducing selection bias.

scenario: People who start wearing a mask during flu season report fewer colds over the next two months.
claim: Wearing a mask prevents colds.
label: NO
causal_structure: Risk-averse people both wear masks and avoid exposure in other ways.
key_insight: Masking is bundled with other protective behaviors.
hidden_timestamp: Did people also change other behaviors (avoiding crowds) when they started masking?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If masking coincided with avoiding crowds, the relationship is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If masking changed while other behaviors stayed constant, a causal effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Masking may correlate with other protective behaviors that also reduce colds.
gold_rationale: Risk aversion and exposure avoidance (Z) influence both masking (X) and cold incidence (Y).

scenario: Shoppers who use price-comparison browser extensions pay less on average per online purchase.
claim: Price-comparison extensions reduce purchase prices.
label: NO
causal_structure: More frugal consumers use extensions and also search more before buying, lowering prices.
key_insight: User traits confound the association.
hidden_timestamp: Were these shoppers already paying less before installing the extension?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If they were already paying less, the extension is not shown to be causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If prices dropped after installation with similar shopping patterns, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Lower prices may reflect frugality and shopping effort rather than the extension itself.
gold_rationale: Frugality/search effort (Z) affects both extension use (X) and price paid (Y).

scenario: People who start a home workout program report feeling more energetic after two weeks.
claim: The workout program caused the energy increase.
label: NO
causal_structure: People adopting workouts often change sleep and diet simultaneously.
key_insight: Bundled lifestyle improvements confound the effect.
hidden_timestamp: Did sleep or diet change at the same time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If sleep/diet changed too, workouts alone are not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only exercise changed, effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Energy gains may result from multiple simultaneous lifestyle changes.
gold_rationale: Sleep and diet confound the observed energy increase.

scenario: Workers who switch to standing desks complete more tasks per day.
claim: Standing desks increased productivity.
label: NO
causal_structure: More motivated workers choose ergonomic improvements.
key_insight: Self-selection into productivity habits.
hidden_timestamp: Were these workers already more productive before switching?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If they were already productive, desk change is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If output rose only after switching, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Standing desk adoption may reflect pre-existing motivation.
gold_rationale: Selection bias explains productivity differences.

scenario: People who switch to decaf coffee report less anxiety.
claim: Decaf coffee reduced anxiety.
label: NO
causal_structure: Switching to decaf often coincides with broader stress reduction efforts.
key_insight: Other stress-reducing behaviors confound the result.
hidden_timestamp: Did other lifestyle stress changes occur?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If broader stress efforts occurred, decaf alone is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If nothing else changed, effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Reduced anxiety may reflect broader stress management, not just coffee choice.
gold_rationale: Lifestyle changes confound the association.

scenario: People who start using a sleep tracking app report better sleep quality.
claim: The app caused better sleep.
label: NO
causal_structure: App users also adopt healthier sleep routines.
key_insight: Behavior changes accompany tracking.
hidden_timestamp: Did bedtime routines change when the app was adopted?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If routines improved, app alone is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If nothing else changed, effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Tracking may correlate with better sleep habits rather than cause them.
gold_rationale: Routine improvements confound the relationship.

scenario: Students who form study groups score higher on exams.
claim: Study groups caused higher scores.
label: NO
causal_structure: Motivated students self-select into study groups.
key_insight: Motivation confounds the effect.
hidden_timestamp: Were these students already performing well?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If they were already strong students, groups are not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If performance rose only after joining, effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Study groups may simply reflect higher motivation.
gold_rationale: Selection bias explains higher performance.

scenario: People who buy new running shoes start running more miles per week.
claim: Buying new shoes caused increased running.
label: NO
causal_structure: People buy shoes because they already plan to run more.
key_insight: Intent to train precedes shoe purchase.
hidden_timestamp: Did mileage increase before the shoes were purchased?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If people planned mileage increases before buying shoes, purchase is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If mileage jumped only after the purchase without prior intent change, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Shoe purchases may reflect pre-existing training plans.
gold_rationale: Training motivation drives both shoe purchase and running mileage.

scenario: People who start meal-prepping on Sundays lose weight over the next month.
claim: Meal prepping caused the weight loss.
label: NO
causal_structure: Meal prep often happens alongside diet and exercise changes.
key_insight: Bundled behavior change.
hidden_timestamp: Did calorie intake or exercise change simultaneously?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If diet/exercise also changed, meal prep alone is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only prep changed, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Weight loss may be driven by multiple simultaneous changes.
gold_rationale: Diet and exercise confound the relationship.

scenario: Teams that adopt a new project management tool report faster task completion.
claim: The tool caused faster completion.
label: NO
causal_structure: Tool adoption often coincides with broader process changes.
key_insight: Multiple simultaneous productivity initiatives.
hidden_timestamp: Were workflows or incentives changed at the same time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If broader process changes occurred, the tool is not isolated.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only the tool changed, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Faster work may reflect broader operational changes.
gold_rationale: Process reform confounds tool adoption.

scenario: Students who attend optional review sessions score higher on the final exam.
claim: Review sessions caused higher scores.
label: NO
causal_structure: Stronger or more motivated students choose to attend.
key_insight: Self-selection.
hidden_timestamp: Were attendees already higher-performing?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If attendees were already stronger, sessions are not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If scores rose only after attendance, effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Attendance reflects motivation, not necessarily session impact.
gold_rationale: Motivation drives both attendance and performance.

scenario: People who start wearing blue-light glasses report fewer headaches.
claim: Blue-light glasses reduce headaches.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: People may also change screen habits or ergonomics.
key_insight: Multiple changes after symptom onset.
hidden_timestamp: Did screen time or posture change simultaneously?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If other habits changed, glasses alone are not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only glasses changed, effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Headache reduction may reflect broader behavior changes.
gold_rationale: Ergonomic and screen-time adjustments confound results.

scenario: Investors who subscribe to a premium newsletter outperform the market.
claim: The newsletter caused higher returns.
label: NO
causal_structure: More sophisticated investors self-select into paid advice.
key_insight: Investor skill confounding.
hidden_timestamp: Were subscribers already outperforming before subscribing?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If prior performance was higher, subscription is not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If returns improved only after subscribing, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Subscribers may already be more skilled investors.
gold_rationale: Investor sophistication confounds the association.

scenario: People who buy a new mattress report less back pain after two weeks.
claim: A new mattress caused the back pain reduction.
label: NO
causal_structure: People often buy mattresses during a pain spike; pain may naturally improve regardless and/or with concurrent therapy.
key_insight: Peak-triggered adoption can mimic treatment effects.
hidden_timestamp: Was the mattress purchased right after an unusually bad back-pain week?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If purchased during a flare-up, improvement may be regression to the mean or co-interventions.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If purchase timing is unrelated to flares and pain drops vs. a control, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If people buy a mattress when pain is worst, later improvement doesn’t prove the mattress caused it.
gold_rationale: Regression to the mean and concurrent therapy can explain the pain decrease.

scenario: Commuters who start biking to work report better mood after one month.
claim: Biking to work caused improved mood.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: Mood can improve due to seasonality or unrelated life changes occurring around the same time as switching commutes.
key_insight: Before/after narratives need a counterfactual.
hidden_timestamp: Did the commute switch coincide with better weather or other life changes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If other mood drivers changed at the same time, the biking effect isn’t identified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the switch is exogenous (e.g., parking removed) or randomized and mood improves, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Mood improvement after a commute change could be driven by other simultaneous changes.
gold_rationale: Time-varying factors and co-interventions can explain the observed improvement.

scenario: Users who enable 'dark mode' on their phone report less eye strain.
claim: Dark mode caused less eye strain.
label: NO
causal_structure: People who enable dark mode may also change brightness/screen time and may report improvement due to expectations.
key_insight: Self-reported outcomes + co-changes confound the claim.
hidden_timestamp: Did screen time or brightness change when dark mode was enabled?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If other screen behaviors changed, dark mode alone isn’t identified as causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If objective measures improve holding screen time constant, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Self-reported eye strain changes don’t isolate dark mode from other screen habit changes.
gold_rationale: Behavior changes and expectation effects confound the association.

scenario: A tutoring center reports students who attend 10+ sessions improve more than students who attend fewer sessions.
claim: Attending 10+ sessions caused more improvement.
label: NO
causal_structure: Only students who stick with tutoring (often the most motivated/supported) reach 10+ sessions.
key_insight: Conditioning on adherence biases effects upward.
hidden_timestamp: Do struggling or unmotivated students drop out before reaching 10 sessions?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If dropout is related to motivation/results, the 10+ estimate is biased.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment to 10 sessions is randomized/encouraged and analyzed intent-to-treat, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Comparing heavy attenders to light attenders is confounded by persistence and support.
gold_rationale: Adherence is a post-treatment selection variable correlated with outcomes.

scenario: A company offers a wellness stipend; employees who use it have fewer sick days.
claim: Using the wellness stipend caused fewer sick days.
label: NO
causal_structure: Healthier, more engaged employees are more likely to use the stipend and also have fewer sick days.
key_insight: User type drives both stipend use and outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Were stipend users already taking fewer sick days before the benefit started?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If users were healthier beforehand, the relationship is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If usage was randomized or encouraged exogenously and sick days fell, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Stipend use may just identify healthier, more engaged employees.
gold_rationale: Healthy user/engagement confounds stipend use and sick days.

scenario: A hospital compares mortality for patients who received a new drug vs. those who did not, but the drug is given only to patients who arrive early enough to be eligible.
claim: The new drug caused lower mortality.
label: NO
causal_structure: To receive the drug, patients must survive/stay eligible long enough and arrive early, biasing the treated group toward better outcomes.
key_insight: Eligibility windows create non-comparable groups.
hidden_timestamp: Is treatment defined by being alive/eligible at a later time point?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If eligibility requires surviving to treatment time, treated outcomes are biased by immortal time.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If analyzed with time-varying treatment or randomized assignment, bias is reduced.

wise_refusal: If patients must remain eligible long enough to get the drug, lower mortality may reflect immortal time, not the drug.
gold_rationale: Post-baseline eligibility requirements bias comparisons in favor of treated patients.

scenario: People who join a boutique gym lose more weight than people who keep their regular gym membership.
claim: The boutique gym caused more weight loss.
label: NO
causal_structure: People willing to pay for boutique gyms differ systematically (motivation/resources).
key_insight: Willingness to pay and motivation confound.
hidden_timestamp: Were boutique-joiners already increasing training or dieting before joining?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If joiners were already more motivated, the difference is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment is randomized/encouraged and results improve, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Paying for a boutique gym may reflect motivation and resources, not a causal effect.
gold_rationale: Selection into boutique gyms confounds weight outcomes.

scenario: A language learning app reports that users who maintain a 14-day streak learn faster.
claim: A 14-day streak caused faster learning.
label: NO
causal_structure: Only users who persist (often the most motivated/able) achieve streaks; comparing streakers to others biases effects.
key_insight: Streak is a post-treatment adherence metric.
hidden_timestamp: Do users who struggle or get busy drop out before reaching 14 days?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If dropout is related to difficulty/time, streak-based comparisons are biased.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If streak is induced randomly (nudges) and learning improves, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Streak status reflects persistence and time, not necessarily a causal mechanism.
gold_rationale: Adherence-based selection confounds streaks and progress.

scenario: A website shows free shipping only to users with carts above $75; those users end up with higher conversion rates.
claim: Free shipping caused higher conversion.
label: NO
causal_structure: Users with higher intent/cart size are more likely to convert and are also the ones shown free shipping.
key_insight: Treatment is targeted by intent.
hidden_timestamp: Is free shipping triggered by a cart threshold or other intent signals?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If triggered by cart value, conversion differences are confounded by intent.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If randomized A/B at the same cart value, causality is supported.

wise_refusal: If free shipping is shown only to high-intent carts, conversion uplift isn’t identified.
gold_rationale: Intent threshold confounds offer exposure and conversion.

scenario: A city adds more bike lanes and cycling increases while car collisions drop over the next year.
claim: Bike lanes caused fewer car collisions.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: Collision rates can change due to traffic volume, enforcement, or other redesigns happening around rollout.
key_insight: Needs a clean counterfactual and parallel trends.
hidden_timestamp: Were there other safety interventions or traffic changes during the same period?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If other interventions/traffic shifts occurred, attribution to bike lanes is unclear.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there’s a credible control area with parallel pre-trends and only lanes changed, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Before/after citywide trends don’t isolate bike lanes from other changes.
gold_rationale: Time-varying confounders and non-parallel trends make the effect uncertain.

scenario: Employees who attend leadership training report higher job satisfaction in an internal survey.
claim: Leadership training caused higher satisfaction.
label: NO
causal_structure: Training seats are often given to high-potential employees who already have better experiences and may respond more positively.
key_insight: Targeted enrollment + subjective outcome measurement.
hidden_timestamp: Were attendees nominated/selected based on performance or engagement?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If selected as high-potential, satisfaction differences are confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If training access is randomized and satisfaction improves, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If only high-potential employees attend, survey differences don’t prove training caused satisfaction.
gold_rationale: Selection into training and survey response confound the relationship.

scenario: Patients who receive a follow-up text reminder are more likely to take their medication, but the reminder is sent only to patients who missed a refill in the past.
claim: The reminder caused better adherence.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: The reminder group is selected based on past non-adherence; their adherence may rebound naturally or differ systematically.
key_insight: Targeting breaks comparability; could even bias toward underestimating or overestimating.
hidden_timestamp: Is reminder assignment determined by prior non-adherence rather than randomization?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If targeted by past misses, comparisons to non-reminded patients are confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If reminders are randomized within similar adherence history strata, causality is supported.

wise_refusal: Targeted reminders don’t give a clean causal estimate without proper randomization or matching.
gold_rationale: Selection on prior behavior confounds reminder exposure and future adherence.

scenario: People who start drinking electrolyte packets daily report fewer headaches.
claim: Electrolyte packets caused fewer headaches.
label: NO
causal_structure: People often add electrolytes as part of broader hydration/health changes that also reduce headaches.
key_insight: Hydration and lifestyle changes confound.
hidden_timestamp: Did water intake or alcohol consumption change at the same time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If hydration/other habits changed, electrolytes alone aren’t identified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only electrolytes changed and other factors stayed stable, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Headache improvements may reflect hydration and other behavior changes, not the packets.
gold_rationale: Hydration and lifestyle confound the association.

scenario: A school rolls out a new reading curriculum only in classrooms where teachers volunteered to pilot it; those classrooms show larger test score gains.
claim: The new curriculum caused the higher gains.
label: NO
causal_structure: More enthusiastic/effective teachers volunteered and would likely produce better gains regardless of curriculum.
key_insight: Teacher self-selection confounds the curriculum effect.
hidden_timestamp: Were volunteer teachers already outperforming before the pilot?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If volunteer teachers were stronger at baseline, gains aren’t causal evidence of curriculum.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If classrooms were randomized to curriculum, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Volunteer pilots confound curriculum effects with teacher differences.
gold_rationale: Teacher quality affects both curriculum adoption and student gains.

scenario: A company gives bonuses to departments that exceed quarterly targets; those departments later have higher employee retention.
claim: Bonuses caused higher retention.
label: NO
causal_structure: Bonuses are conditional on performance, and strong departments also retain better for many reasons.
key_insight: Eligibility is endogenous to department quality.
hidden_timestamp: Were bonuses granted based on hitting targets rather than random assignment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only high-performing departments get bonuses, retention differences are confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If bonuses are randomized or rolled out broadly with a control group, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If bonuses are given to already-strong departments, retention may reflect department quality, not bonuses.
gold_rationale: Department performance/management confounds bonus receipt and retention.
