hidden_timestamp: Was the widget randomly assigned, or triggered by cart/intent thresholds?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If triggered by intent/cart size, the uplift is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If randomized A/B, causal effect is supported.

wise_refusal: If the widget is targeted, higher order value isn’t causal evidence.
gold_rationale: Intent signals influence both widget exposure and order value.

scenario: Drivers who switch to an electric car report spending less on transportation overall after 6 months.
claim: Switching to an EV caused lower transportation spending.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: Spending shifts can be driven by mileage changes and external price changes, not the car itself.
key_insight: Need to isolate mileage and price environment.
hidden_timestamp: Did driving habits (miles driven) change after the switch, or did gas prices change during the period?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If miles/gas prices changed, the spending drop isn’t identified as EV-caused.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If mileage is stable and prices controlled, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Lower spending could reflect changes in miles driven or fuel prices, not the EV switch itself.
gold_rationale: Time-varying factors (prices, mileage) confound before/after spending comparisons.

scenario: A creator reports that after they started posting daily, their follower count increased quickly.
claim: Posting daily caused the follower growth.
label: NO
causal_structure: Growth can be driven by platform dynamics or a viral event coincident with daily posting.
key_insight: Single before/after narrative isn’t causal.
hidden_timestamp: Was there a viral post or platform recommendation change during the same period?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a viral event occurred, it can explain growth independent of posting frequency.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If growth systematically increases with randomized posting cadence, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Follower growth after a behavior change doesn’t prove that behavior caused it.
gold_rationale: Time-varying shocks (viral content, algorithm) can explain the increase.

scenario: Among patients with chronic pain, those who take an 'as-needed' medication report lower pain at their next appointment; the appointment dates vary widely by patient.
claim: The medication caused lower pain.
label: NO
causal_structure: Different follow-up windows and baseline severity make comparisons invalid; pain fluctuates over time.
key_insight: Outcome timing + baseline mismatch break causal inference.
hidden_timestamp: Are medicated and unmedicated patients compared at different time horizons or severities?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If time-to-follow-up and baseline pain differ, the comparison is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If timing and baseline severity are matched (or randomized), causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Without aligning baseline severity and follow-up timing, you can’t attribute pain differences to the medication.
gold_rationale: Timing heterogeneity and baseline severity confound the observed association.

scenario: A company offers flexible hours only to teams that hit performance targets; those teams later report lower burnout.
claim: Flexible hours caused lower burnout.
label: NO
causal_structure: Policy access depends on team performance/management quality that also affects burnout.
key_insight: Eligibility is endogenous to team quality.
hidden_timestamp: Was flexibility granted conditional on hitting targets (or manager discretion)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If eligibility depends on performance/management, the effect is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If flexibility is randomized/rolled out broadly with a control group, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If only high-performing teams get flexibility, lower burnout may reflect team quality, not the policy.
gold_rationale: Targeting/selection into flexibility biases the burnout comparison.

scenario: A test-prep company claims students who buy the 'premium' plan improve more than students on the basic plan.
claim: Premium plan caused more improvement.
label: NO
causal_structure: Premium purchasers differ in motivation and resources, which drive improvement.
key_insight: Plan choice is endogenous.
hidden_timestamp: Were premium users already studying more or scoring higher at baseline?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If baseline motivation/resources differ, the premium effect is confounded.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If plans are randomly assigned (or near-random upsell), causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Paying for premium often correlates with motivation and time, so it’s not causal evidence.
gold_rationale: WTP and motivation affect both plan choice and outcomes.

scenario: People who check their portfolio daily are more likely to sell during market dips.
claim: Checking daily causes panic selling.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: More anxious or inexperienced investors may both check more and sell more.
key_insight: Direction + confounding unclear.
hidden_timestamp: Did anxious investors start checking more before the selling behavior, or was checking induced exogenously?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If anxiety/inexperience drives both, causality isn’t identified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If checking frequency is randomized (nudges) and selling rises, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Frequent checking may reflect investor type rather than cause panic selling.
gold_rationale: Risk tolerance and anxiety confound the checking–selling relationship.

scenario: A study finds people who take a daily supplement have fewer sick days, but supplement adherence is measured only via self-report at the end of the month.
claim: The supplement caused fewer sick days.
label: NO
causal_structure: Health-conscious people may both be healthier and over-report adherence; exposure measurement is biased.
key_insight: Biased measurement can create associations without true effects.
hidden_timestamp: Is adherence objectively tracked (pill bottle/app) or only end-of-month recall?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If adherence is self-reported, correlated misreporting can explain the association.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If adherence is objectively measured and randomized, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Self-reported adherence can be biased and correlated with health behaviors, so it’s not causal evidence.
gold_rationale: Recall bias + healthy-user confounding can generate the pattern.

scenario: A teacher says students who do the optional 'extra credit' packet improve the most, and the teacher highlights only the top improvers in a write-up.
claim: Extra credit packets caused the biggest improvements.
label: NO
causal_structure: Focusing on top improvers (and optional participation) excludes non-improvers and biases conclusions.
key_insight: Highlighting successes is not evidence of causation.
hidden_timestamp: Are non-completers or non-improvers omitted from the analysis/story?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only top improvers are shown, conclusions are survivorship/selection bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all students are analyzed with baseline adjustment or random assignment, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Showcasing only the biggest improvers doesn’t show the packet caused improvement.
gold_rationale: Survivorship/selection plus motivation confound the observed pattern.

scenario: After a city runs a big anti-smoking campaign, smoking rates drop over the next year.
claim: The campaign caused smoking rates to drop.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: Rates could decline due to broader trends or simultaneous policy changes.
key_insight: Need a counterfactual (control city / synthetic control).
hidden_timestamp: Did taxes, enforcement, or national trends shift during the same window?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If other policies/trends changed, campaign effect isn’t identified.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there’s a strong control group with parallel trends, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: A before/after city trend can’t isolate the campaign from other simultaneous changes.
gold_rationale: Time-varying confounders and secular trends make attribution uncertain.

scenario: A productivity app claims that users who hit 'inbox zero' each day feel less stressed, and the app starts optimizing notifications to maximize 'inbox zero' days.
claim: Maximizing inbox zero causes lower stress.
label: NO

Z: Goodharting: superficial clearing vs. real workload reduction

causal_structure: Optimizing a proxy (inbox zero) can change behavior (archiving/ignoring) without reducing actual stressors.
key_insight: Proxy optimization can decouple metric from true outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Did behavior shift to ‘clear’ inbox without reducing workload (e.g., auto-archive)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If users game the metric, inbox zero isn’t causally tied to real stress reduction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If workload truly drops and stress drops with objective measures, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If the app pushes people to game inbox zero, the metric can’t support causal claims about stress.
gold_rationale: Goodharting breaks the interpretation of inbox zero as a causal driver of lower stress.

scenario: A hospital reports that patients who receive surgery have lower mortality, but only patients stable enough are approved by anesthesia for surgery.
claim: Surgery caused lower mortality.
label: NO
causal_structure: Stability determines treatment eligibility and also predicts survival, making groups incomparable.
key_insight: Clinical eligibility is a strong confounder.
hidden_timestamp: Was surgery approval contingent on baseline stability measures?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only stable patients get surgery, lower mortality can reflect selection, not causation.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assignment is near-random (e.g., cutoff) or properly adjusted, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If surgery is offered only to stable patients, the mortality difference isn’t causal evidence.
gold_rationale: Eligibility/stability affects both treatment and outcome, biasing the comparison.

scenario: Teams that do more retrospectives per quarter ship more features, so leadership increases the retro count target.
claim: More retrospectives cause higher shipping velocity.
label: NO
causal_structure: High-performing teams may do more retros; increasing retro count can create low-quality meetings without improving shipping.
key_insight: Metric increases don’t necessarily cause outcome improvements.
hidden_timestamp: Did teams add low-quality retros to hit targets (without changing process quality)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If retro count is gamed, it’s not a causal driver of shipping.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If structured retro quality improves and velocity rises in randomized rollout, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: More retros can be a proxy for team quality, and retro-count targeting can be gamed.
gold_rationale: Selection + Goodhart effects break causal interpretation of retro frequency.

scenario: People who buy air purifiers report fewer allergy symptoms, but many purchased them right after a severe allergy flare.
claim: Air purifiers caused fewer allergy symptoms.
label: NO
causal_structure: Symptoms often improve after peaks due to natural cycles or season changes; purchases occur at peaks.
key_insight: Peak-triggered adoption biases before/after comparisons.
hidden_timestamp: Did purchases coincide with a symptom peak or seasonal peak that later declined?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If bought at a flare peak or season peak, improvement may be regression/seasonality.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If adoption timing is unrelated to peaks and symptoms drop vs. a control, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If the purifier is bought during a flare or pollen peak, symptom drops don’t prove causation.
gold_rationale: Regression/seasonality and co-medication can explain symptom reductions.

scenario: A university gives scholarships to students with GPAs above 3.8; scholarship recipients later have higher graduation rates than non-recipients.
claim: Receiving the scholarship caused higher graduation rates.
label: AMBIGUOUS
causal_structure: If compared broadly, recipients differ in baseline GPA. Near the cutoff, assignment may be quasi-random and can support causality.
key_insight: Only near-threshold comparisons support causal inference.
hidden_timestamp: Is the analysis using a narrow window around the 3.8 cutoff (RD), or a broad recipient vs. non-recipient comparison?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If it’s a broad comparison, baseline GPA confounds the effect (NO).
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If it’s RD near the cutoff with smooth covariates, a causal effect is plausible (YES/AMBIGUOUS depending on validity checks).

wise_refusal: Unless you compare students right around the GPA cutoff, scholarship recipients aren’t comparable to others.
gold_rationale: Cutoff-based assignment can identify causality locally; broad comparisons are confounded by baseline GPA.

scenario: A company introduced standing desks and employee back pain complaints decreased over the next quarter.
claim: Standing desks reduced back pain.
label: NO
causal_structure: Back pain may have decreased due to ergonomics education or lighter workloads.
key_insight: Multiple workplace changes confound the intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Were ergonomics workshops introduced at the same time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If training or workload changed, desks alone are not causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only desks changed, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Without isolating desk installation from other changes, we cannot attribute reduced pain to desks.
gold_rationale: Concurrent ergonomic improvements (Z) may explain pain reduction.

scenario: A school replaced soda machines with water dispensers and students’ BMI decreased that year.
claim: Removing soda machines caused BMI reduction.
label: NO
causal_structure: BMI may have dropped due to increased physical activity or education.
key_insight: Other health initiatives confound the intervention.
hidden_timestamp: Did PE hours increase the same year?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If exercise programs expanded, soda removal is not shown causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no other health changes occurred, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: BMI changes could reflect broader school health programs.
gold_rationale: Concurrent exercise or education programs (Z) confound the effect.

scenario: After installing a productivity tracking app, employee output metrics rose.
claim: The tracking app increased productivity.
label: NO
causal_structure: Output may have risen because deadlines tightened, not because of the app.
key_insight: Management changes confound intervention effects.
hidden_timestamp: Were new deadlines or quotas introduced at the same time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If deadlines increased, productivity rise is not attributable to the app.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If only the app changed, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Without controlling for managerial changes, causation cannot be assigned to the app.
gold_rationale: Work pressure (Z) may drive output independent of tracking.

scenario: A clinic started sending weekly SMS reminders to patients with hypertension, and average systolic blood pressure fell over the next 3 months.
claim: SMS reminders caused blood pressure to fall.
label: NO
causal_structure: Patients who opt into SMS may also be more adherent and more likely to attend follow-ups where meds are adjusted.
key_insight: Opt-in interventions select motivated participants.
hidden_timestamp: Did the blood pressure drop primarily among patients who also attended medication adjustment visits?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If most improvement occurred among those with med changes or counseling, SMS alone is not shown causal.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If improvement occurred without other care changes, SMS is more plausibly causal.

wise_refusal: Without separating opt-in motivation and concurrent care changes from the reminders, we can’t attribute the blood pressure drop to SMS.
gold_rationale: Selection into the SMS program and correlated adherence/care intensity (Z) can explain the observed improvement.

scenario: A city launched a job-training program and participants’ earnings increased one year later compared to their earnings before the program.
claim: The training program caused higher earnings.
label: NO
causal_structure: Participants may enroll when they are at unusually low earnings; earnings can rebound naturally, especially if the economy improves.
key_insight: Before/after comparisons can reflect natural rebound.
hidden_timestamp: Were participants selected because they had recent income shocks right before enrollment?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If enrollment followed unusually low earnings, the increase may be regression to the mean.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If earnings were stable pre-program and only rose after, training is more plausible.

wise_refusal: A before/after increase doesn’t isolate training effects from regression to the mean or broader labor market changes.
gold_rationale: Selection at a low point plus economic recovery (Z) can produce earnings increases without a training causal effect.

scenario: A state increased teacher pay, and the following year average student test scores rose statewide.
claim: Raising teacher pay caused higher test scores.
label: NO
causal_structure: Aggregate score changes may be driven by test redesign or curriculum reforms; individual causal pathways are unclear from state averages.
key_insight: Aggregate shifts don’t identify individual-level causation.
hidden_timestamp: Did the test format or scoring rubric change the same year as the pay increase?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the test/curriculum changed, score increases can’t be attributed to pay.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If assessments and curricula were unchanged, pay effects are more plausible but still unproven.

wise_refusal: Statewide correlations can reflect concurrent reforms or measurement changes; they don’t isolate the pay increase’s causal effect.
gold_rationale: Ecological inference from aggregate scores is invalid when other statewide changes (Z) could drive the trend.

scenario: A county adopted body cameras for police officers, and reported use-of-force incidents decreased the next year.
claim: Body cameras caused the decrease in use-of-force.
label: NO
causal_structure: The number of *reported* incidents can change if reporting rules tighten/loosen or if officers reclassify events.
key_insight: A drop in reported outcomes can be a measurement artifact.
hidden_timestamp: Did the department change how use-of-force incidents are defined or logged after cameras were introduced?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If definitions/reporting changed, the drop may be a recording artifact rather than a true reduction.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If measurement stayed constant, cameras are a more plausible contributor.

wise_refusal: Without confirming consistent reporting definitions and logging practices, we can’t treat a decline in reported incidents as a camera causal effect.
gold_rationale: Measurement changes (Z) can reduce recorded incidents even if true behavior doesn’t change.

scenario: A basketball team hired a new defensive coach and the team’s defensive rating improved over the season.
claim: Hiring the defensive coach caused the improvement.
label: NO
causal_structure: The coach may have been hired *because* the team invested in defense (better players). Conditioning on teams that hire such coaches can induce spurious links.
key_insight: Conditioning on selection into an 'improvement effort' can induce bias.
hidden_timestamp: Were key defensive players acquired or returning from injury around the same time as the coach hire?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If roster changes drove defense, attributing to the coach is invalid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If roster/schedule were stable, coach causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Without separating roster and schedule effects from coaching, the observed improvement can’t be assigned to the coach hire.
gold_rationale: Selection into hiring (linked to roster investment) creates collider-like bias; improvements may be due to roster/schedule (Z).

scenario: A city banned indoor smoking and hospital admissions for respiratory issues declined over the next 2 years.
claim: The smoking ban caused fewer respiratory admissions.
label: NO
causal_structure: Admissions vary strongly by influenza waves and pollution trends; timing alone doesn’t isolate the ban effect.
key_insight: Time trends can masquerade as intervention effects.
hidden_timestamp: Did admissions decline start before the ban took effect (or coincide with milder flu seasons)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the decline began before the ban or tracks flu/pollution, ban causality is unsupported.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If decline starts after the ban with stable flu/pollution, ban effect is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Without ruling out contemporaneous time-varying factors like flu severity and pollution, we cannot attribute admissions decline to the ban.
gold_rationale: Temporal confounding (Z) can create post-policy improvements even without a true policy effect.

scenario: A retailer introduced a loyalty program and repeat purchase rates rose among enrolled customers.
claim: The loyalty program caused repeat purchases.
label: NO
causal_structure: Customers who enroll are already more loyal and may be targeted with discounts.
key_insight: Enrollees differ from non-enrollees.
hidden_timestamp: Were promotions/discounts disproportionately sent to enrolled customers?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If enrollees get more promos or were already loyal, repeat purchases aren’t attributable to the program.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If enrollment was automatic and promos equal, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Enrollment selection and targeted marketing can explain higher repeat rates without a causal program effect.
gold_rationale: Selection and promotional confounding (Z) drive repeat purchase differences.

scenario: A utility rolled out smart thermostats in one neighborhood and average electricity usage dropped compared to the previous year.
claim: Smart thermostats caused lower electricity usage.
label: NO
causal_structure: Usage can drop due to milder temperatures or higher prices, independent of thermostats.
key_insight: Year-over-year comparisons confound with weather and prices.
hidden_timestamp: Was the rollout year significantly milder or were electricity rates higher?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If weather/prices changed, usage drops can’t be attributed to thermostats.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If weather/prices were stable, thermostats are more plausible.

wise_refusal: Without controlling for weather and price changes, the usage drop doesn’t identify a thermostat causal effect.
gold_rationale: Time-varying confounders (Z) can explain the observed reduction.

scenario: A streaming service deployed a new recommendation model and average watch time per user increased the same month.
claim: The new recommender caused higher watch time.
label: NO
causal_structure: Watch time may rise due to a popular new show or marketing rather than algorithm changes.
key_insight: Attribution requires isolating product changes from content shocks.
hidden_timestamp: Did a major flagship series launch at the same time as the model release?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a content/marketing shock occurred, increased watch time isn’t attributable to the model.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If content cadence and marketing were stable, the model is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Without separating recommender changes from content and marketing shocks, causality can’t be assigned to the model.
gold_rationale: Confounding by content releases and campaigns (Z) can fully explain higher watch time.

scenario: A school district adopted a new reading curriculum, and reading scores improved among 3rd graders compared to last year’s 3rd graders.
claim: The new curriculum caused the score improvements.
label: NO
causal_structure: Comparing different cohorts across years mixes cohort composition and teacher staffing changes.
key_insight: Different cohorts ≠ counterfactual for the same students.
hidden_timestamp: Were the same students/teachers measured, or are these different cohorts with different composition?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If cohorts differ meaningfully, improvements can’t be attributed to the curriculum.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the same cohort is tracked longitudinally with stable staffing, curriculum is more plausible.

wise_refusal: A year-to-year cohort comparison doesn’t isolate curriculum effects from cohort and staffing changes.
gold_rationale: Ecological/cohort confounding (Z) can drive score differences independent of the curriculum.

scenario: Patients given a new cholesterol medication showed lower LDL at their next visit, and those with the largest LDL drops were also the patients who returned for follow-up testing.
claim: The new medication caused the LDL reduction.
label: NO
causal_structure: Conditioning on having follow-up labs (a collider affected by adherence and improvement) can bias observed medication-outcome association.
key_insight: Only observing follow-ups can induce spurious effects.
hidden_timestamp: Were LDL outcomes computed only among patients who returned for follow-up testing?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only follow-up patients are analyzed, selection on follow-up can inflate apparent medication benefit.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all patients are followed regardless of attendance, the estimate is less biased.

wise_refusal: If LDL is analyzed only among follow-up attendees, selection on follow-up can create a biased medication effect estimate.
gold_rationale: Follow-up attendance is influenced by adherence and perceived improvement (Z), inducing collider bias in observed outcomes.

scenario: A jurisdiction implemented a new pretrial risk assessment tool, and the pretrial detention rate fell among defendants scored as 'low risk'.
claim: The tool caused lower detention rates for low-risk defendants.
label: NO
causal_structure: The tool may redefine who is labeled 'low risk' and may coincide with guidance that changes detention practices, confounding measurement with policy.
key_insight: Changing labels can change measured outcomes without changing behavior.
hidden_timestamp: Did the criteria for 'low risk' change when the tool was introduced (reclassifying defendants)?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If classification changed, lower detention among 'low risk' can be a re-labeling artifact.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If classification stayed consistent, the tool may be contributing—but still needs isolation from policy guidance.

wise_refusal: If 'low risk' is defined differently post-tool, comparing detention rates within that label doesn’t identify a causal effect.
gold_rationale: Measurement/classification changes (Z) can produce apparent improvements without true causal impact.

scenario: A running club started a new warm-up routine, and injury reports decreased. However, only runners who stayed in the club for the full season were included in the injury analysis.
claim: The warm-up routine reduced injuries.
label: NO
causal_structure: Injured runners may drop out and be excluded, making remaining members look healthier.
key_insight: Only analyzing 'survivors' biases outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Were runners who left mid-season (possibly due to injury) excluded from the injury counts?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If dropouts are excluded, injury decline can be survivorship bias.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If all runners are tracked regardless of dropout, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If injured runners disproportionately dropped out and were excluded, the injury decline may be a survivorship artifact.
gold_rationale: Survivorship bias (Z) can make injuries appear lower among those who remain.

scenario: A ride-share company increased prices during peak hours and average driver earnings per hour increased that month.
claim: Higher prices caused higher driver earnings per hour.
label: NO
causal_structure: Prices may have been raised in response to anticipated demand surges; earnings rise due to demand, not the price change itself.
key_insight: Price changes can be endogenous to demand.
hidden_timestamp: Was the price increase triggered by forecasted demand spikes (events, weather) that also increase earnings?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the price change responds to demand shocks, earnings increases aren’t attributable to price.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If prices increased exogenously with stable demand, causality is more plausible.

wise_refusal: If pricing is adjusted in response to demand surges, observed earnings changes don’t identify the causal effect of higher prices.
gold_rationale: Reverse causation/endogeneity via demand shocks (Z) can explain higher earnings.

scenario: A park introduced a new 'no feeding wildlife' campaign and the number of wildlife incidents reported by visitors decreased.
claim: The campaign reduced wildlife incidents.
label: NO
causal_structure: Reports may decline if fewer visitors come or if visitors are less likely to report, not because incidents truly fell.
key_insight: A drop in reports can be a reporting change.
hidden_timestamp: Did visitor counts drop or did reporting channels change during the campaign?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If reporting/visitor volume changed, the decline may be measurement-driven.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If reporting and volume were stable, the campaign is more plausible.

wise_refusal: Without verifying stable reporting and visitor volume, fewer reports don’t prove fewer incidents.
gold_rationale: Measurement/reporting changes (Z) can explain the observed decline.

scenario: A team changed its OKRs to focus on 'number of features shipped' and the feature count rose, while user retention fell slightly.
claim: Changing OKRs caused more progress (better product outcomes).
label: NO
causal_structure: Optimizing a proxy metric (features shipped) can degrade true outcomes via gaming and reduced quality.
key_insight: Optimizing the metric can break the goal.
hidden_timestamp: Did QA/testing time decrease or did scope per feature shrink after the OKR change?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If teams gamed the metric or cut QA, the OKR change harmed true outcomes.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If feature quality held constant, OKR change may increase delivery pace but still not guarantee better outcomes.

wise_refusal: An OKR that pushes feature count can drive metric inflation and worse user outcomes; feature count is not proof of real progress.
gold_rationale: This is a Goodhart trap: the proxy metric is optimized while true quality/retention suffers (Z).

scenario: A startup’s API had 6 outages in a month. The team wonders: if they had implemented circuit breakers two months earlier (X’), would they have avoided all 6 outages (Y)?
claim: If they had implemented circuit breakers earlier, they would have avoided all 6 outages.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X’: Circuit breakers deployed two months earlier
Z: Outage root causes (db overload vs deploy bugs)

causal_structure: Circuit breakers only prevent cascading failures from dependency timeouts; they do not prevent outages caused by deploy bugs or primary database failures.
key_insight: The counterfactual depends on what actually caused the outages.
hidden_timestamp: How many of the 6 outages were dependency-cascade incidents vs deploy/db incidents?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If most outages were cascade failures from downstream timeouts, earlier circuit breakers likely prevent many (possibly all) outages → VALID/near-valid.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If most outages were deploy regressions or primary DB failures, circuit breakers would not prevent them → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Circuit breakers (X’) can prevent some classes of cascading dependency failures, but they won’t stop outages driven by deploy bugs or primary database failure (Z). Whether all 6 outages would be avoided depends on the outage root-cause mix.
gold_rationale: You can’t assert ‘all 6’ without mapping outages to failure modes. Circuit breakers only address a subset of mechanisms; different structural causes (Z) change the counterfactual outcome.

scenario: A patient with sepsis arrived hypotensive and received antibiotics 3 hours after triage. The question is: if antibiotics had been given within 1 hour (X’), would the patient have avoided ICU admission (Y)?
claim: If antibiotics were given within 1 hour, the patient would not have needed the ICU.
label: CONDITIONAL

trap.subtype_name: Earlier treatment may or may not flip outcome

causal_structure: Earlier antibiotics can reduce progression, but ICU admission also depends on baseline severity and whether source control occurs quickly.
key_insight: Timing matters, but only within the context of severity and other interventions.
hidden_timestamp: Was the patient already in refractory shock (high lactate/vasopressors) before antibiotics at 1 hour would realistically take effect?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If severity was moderate and source control was prompt, earlier antibiotics plausibly prevent ICU → VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the patient was already in severe shock needing pressors or delayed source control, ICU likely regardless → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Earlier antibiotics (X’) can change trajectories in some sepsis cases, but ICU need (Y) is strongly driven by baseline severity and source control timing (Z). Without those, you can’t conclude ICU would have been avoided.
gold_rationale: Counterfactual impact of timing depends on where the patient was on the severity curve and whether the infection source was controlled. The same timing change can flip outcomes in mild/moderate cases but not in severe shock.

scenario: A country raised interest rates aggressively in 2022 and entered recession in 2023. People ask: if the central bank had not raised rates (X’), would recession have been avoided (Y)?
claim: If rates had not been raised, the recession would have been avoided.
label: CONDITIONAL

trap.subtype_name: Outcome driven by stochastic macro shocks

causal_structure: Rate hikes reduce demand and can trigger recession, but exogenous supply/energy shocks can cause recession even without hikes.
key_insight: In macro, the counterfactual changes probabilities, not certainties.
hidden_timestamp: How large were external shocks (energy/supply) relative to the contractionary effect of rate hikes?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If recession indicators were mainly demand-driven and shocks were mild, no hikes could plausibly avert recession → VALID/CONDITIONAL.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If recession was driven primarily by energy/supply shocks or fiscal contraction, recession likely anyway → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Not hiking (X’) could reduce recession risk, but recession (Y) may still occur due to large exogenous shocks and fiscal tightening (Z). Without decomposing demand vs supply drivers, you can’t assert recession would be avoided.
gold_rationale: Counterfactuals in macro are probabilistic and multi-causal. Removing one policy lever doesn’t uniquely determine the outcome when other shocks are large and concurrent.

scenario: A driver hit a pedestrian at night. The pedestrian wasn’t wearing reflective clothing. People ask: if the pedestrian had worn reflective clothing (X’), would the accident have been prevented (Y)?
claim: If the pedestrian wore reflective clothing, the accident would not have happened.
label: CONDITIONAL

trap.subtype_name: Assuming one change deterministically prevents outcome

causal_structure: Reflective clothing increases visibility, but crash avoidance also depends on driver behavior and environment.
key_insight: Visibility helps, but doesn’t deterministically prevent crashes.
hidden_timestamp: Was the driver impaired or traveling so fast that detection distance wouldn’t have changed avoidance?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If driver was attentive, near speed limit, and lighting was poor, reflectors likely increase detection and could prevent crash → VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If driver was impaired/excessively speeding, crash may occur regardless of visibility gains → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Reflective clothing (X’) can increase detection distance, but whether it prevents the accident (Y) depends on driver speed/impairment and lighting (Z). You can’t claim prevention without those details.
gold_rationale: The outcome hinges on stopping distance and reaction time. Reflectors shift perception distance, which only matters if the driver could and would react in time.

scenario: A striker missed a penalty in a knockout match, and the team was eliminated. Fans ask: if the striker had scored the penalty (X’), would the team have won the tournament (Y)?
claim: If the penalty was scored, they would have won the tournament.
label: INVALID

trap.subtype_name: Single moment blamed for long chain outcome

causal_structure: Scoring the penalty changes that match outcome probability, but winning the entire tournament requires multiple later wins with new contingencies.
key_insight: One event can’t justify a long-chain certainty.
hidden_timestamp: Even if they advance, would later opponents and game states remain the same?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If you only claim they likely advance and increase title odds, that’s reasonable → CONDITIONAL framing.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: Claiming they certainly win the tournament is unsupported → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is INVALID as stated. Scoring the penalty (X’) may change that match, but it doesn’t uniquely determine winning the entire tournament (Y) given later matchups and randomness (Z).
gold_rationale: The claim over-attributes a downstream chain outcome to a single upstream event. The correct statement is about probability, not certainty.

scenario: You left home at 8:10am and arrived late because of a freeway accident that happened at 8:05am. You ask: if you had left at 7:55am (X’), would you have arrived on time (Y)?
claim: If I left at 7:55am, I would have arrived on time.
label: CONDITIONAL

trap.subtype_name: Depends on whether you beat the traffic wave

causal_structure: Leaving earlier may avoid the congestion wave, but if the accident already slowed traffic, earlier departure might still be trapped.
key_insight: Earlier isn’t always enough—depends on the congestion window.
hidden_timestamp: Would a 15-minute earlier departure place you past the accident bottleneck before queues formed?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the queue formed after ~8:00 and you would have passed the bottleneck by then, arrival on time is plausible → VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If traffic slowed immediately at 8:05 and remained gridlocked, 7:55 still gets stuck → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Leaving at 7:55 (X’) only guarantees arriving on time (Y) if it places you ahead of the accident’s congestion wave; that depends on accident location and queue formation timing (Z).
gold_rationale: Traffic is path- and time-dependent. Small time shifts can flip outcomes only if they cross the queue-formation threshold.

scenario: A commander chose to attack at dawn rather than wait for reinforcements, and the battle was lost. Historians ask: if the commander had waited 24 hours (X’), would the battle have been won (Y)?
claim: If the commander waited 24 hours, they would have won the battle.
label: CONDITIONAL

trap.subtype_name: Missing info about enemy and logistics

causal_structure: Waiting could strengthen one side, but also gives the enemy time to fortify or receive reinforcements; the net effect is uncertain without countervailing details.
key_insight: Historical counterfactuals hinge on unobserved enemy responses.
hidden_timestamp: Would the enemy have used the extra 24 hours to fortify or receive reinforcements at a similar or greater rate?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If only the commander’s side gains significant reinforcements while enemy remains stable, victory becomes plausible → VALID/CONDITIONAL.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If the enemy also strengthens or fortifies materially, waiting may worsen odds → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Waiting (X’) changes both sides’ opportunities; without knowing enemy reinforcement/fortification and logistics (Z), you can’t conclude the battle would be won (Y).
gold_rationale: Counterfactuals in adversarial settings are game-theoretic: changing your action changes the opponent’s best response. Missing that response makes the claim underdetermined.

scenario: A DTC brand raised prices 15% and saw conversion drop, then revenue fell that quarter. They ask: if they had kept prices the same (X’), would revenue have been higher (Y)?
claim: If we hadn’t raised prices, revenue would have been higher.
label: CONDITIONAL

trap.subtype_name: Revenue depends on unknown demand curve

causal_structure: Revenue depends on price × quantity; without knowing elasticity and concurrent marketing/competitive factors, direction is uncertain.
key_insight: Price changes don’t map deterministically to revenue.
hidden_timestamp: Did the brand also change ad spend or face competitor discounting during the same quarter?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If demand was highly elastic and other factors stable, keeping price could yield higher revenue → VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If demand was inelastic or ad/competition changed, revenue might still fall (or even be lower without the hike) → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Without elasticity estimates and controls for ad spend and competitor pricing (Z), you can’t conclude revenue would be higher under no price increase (X’).
gold_rationale: The sign of the revenue change depends on the slope of the demand curve and concurrent shocks. Observed conversion changes alone don’t identify the counterfactual revenue.

scenario: A town declined to clear brush around the perimeter, and a wildfire later destroyed 40 homes. Residents ask: if the town had cleared brush in spring (X’), would those 40 homes have been saved (Y)?
claim: If brush had been cleared, the 40 homes would have been saved.
label: CONDITIONAL

trap.subtype_name: Mitigation helps but may not cover ember-driven spread

causal_structure: Brush clearing reduces surface fire intensity, but under extreme winds ember spotting can ignite homes regardless; protection depends on multiple mechanisms.
key_insight: One mitigation doesn’t dominate under extreme conditions.
hidden_timestamp: Was the primary destruction mechanism direct flame front or wind-driven ember ignitions into structures?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If flame-front intensity and perimeter fuels were key, brush clearing likely saves many homes → VALID/CONDITIONAL.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If ember spotting dominated under extreme winds and homes weren’t hardened, brush clearing alone likely insufficient → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Brush clearing (X’) can lower fire intensity, but if the event was ember-driven under extreme winds and homes lacked hardening (Z), many homes could still burn. You can’t claim all 40 would be saved.
gold_rationale: Wildfire loss pathways include surface fire, crown fire, and ember intrusion. Clearing brush changes some pathways but not others; the counterfactual depends on which pathway dominated.

scenario: A student failed an exam after pulling an all-nighter. They ask: if they had slept 8 hours (X’), would they have passed (Y)?
claim: If I had slept 8 hours, I would have passed.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Sleep improves cognition, but passing depends heavily on preparation and exam difficulty.
key_insight: Better state helps; it doesn’t create knowledge.
hidden_timestamp: Were you already near the pass threshold based on preparation, or were there major content gaps?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If preparation was close and failure was due to mistakes/slow thinking, sleep could flip outcome → VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there were large content gaps, sleep won’t create knowledge; likely still fail → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Sleeping (X’) likely improves performance, but whether it changes pass/fail (Y) depends on preparation and exam difficulty (Z).
gold_rationale: State variables (sleep) affect execution and recall, but the counterfactual outcome is dominated by underlying knowledge and the cutoff.

scenario: A defendant was convicted after a jury trial where an eyewitness testified with high confidence. Later, DNA evidence excluded the defendant. People ask: if the jury had not heard the eyewitness testimony (X’), would the defendant have been acquitted (Y)?
claim: If the jury hadn’t heard the eyewitness, they would have acquitted.
label: VALID
causal_structure: If the eyewitness was the primary inculpatory evidence and remaining evidence was weak, removing it plausibly flips the verdict.
key_insight: When a single evidence pillar dominates, removing it can flip the legal outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Was the eyewitness the decisive evidence (with little corroboration), or was there strong independent evidence?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If remaining evidence was weak/ambiguous, excluding eyewitness likely yields acquittal → VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If there was strong independent evidence, verdict might remain conviction → CONDITIONAL/INVALID.

wise_refusal: Given the later DNA exclusion and the common outsized weight juries place on confident eyewitnesses, if the eyewitness was the main inculpatory evidence, excluding it (X’) would likely lead to acquittal (Y).
gold_rationale: This is VALID under the typical fact pattern where eyewitness testimony is central and corroboration is limited. The counterfactual hinges on the evidentiary weight distribution; with weak remaining evidence, the verdict plausibly flips.

scenario: A team shipped a new onboarding flow and sign-ups increased 12%. A PM says: if we had not shipped the new onboarding (X’), sign-ups would not have increased (Y).
claim: If we hadn’t shipped the onboarding, sign-ups would not have increased.
label: INVALID
causal_structure: Sign-ups can rise due to external demand shocks even without product changes.
key_insight: You don’t observe the baseline world.
hidden_timestamp: Did any marketing/press/seasonal effect occur in the same period as the onboarding release?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If marketing/press was stable and only onboarding changed, claim becomes plausible → CONDITIONAL.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If marketing/press shifted, the sign-up increase could occur without onboarding → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is INVALID as stated. Without isolating marketing, seasonality, and press (Z), you can’t conclude sign-ups wouldn’t have increased under the old onboarding (X’).
gold_rationale: The claim asserts a unique cause without evidence about the baseline world. External drivers can generate the same observed increase, so the counterfactual is not identified.

scenario: A pitcher was left in too long and gave up a home run. The team lost by 1 run. Fans ask: if the manager had pulled the pitcher earlier (X’), would they have won (Y)?
claim: If the manager pulled the pitcher earlier, they would have won.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Pitcher stayed in; gave up HR

trap.subtype_name: Assuming one decision fixes the game

causal_structure: Pulling the pitcher changes one plate appearance, but replacement performance and later events also matter.
key_insight: You change one branch, not the whole tree.
hidden_timestamp: Was the bullpen replacement significantly better in that matchup (handedness/splits), or was the bullpen depleted?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If a strong reliever with favorable splits was available, win becomes plausible → VALID/CONDITIONAL.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If bullpen was weak/depleted, replacing may still allow runs and loss → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Pulling the pitcher earlier (X’) changes that HR opportunity, but the outcome (Y) depends on who replaces him and subsequent innings (Z).
gold_rationale: Baseball outcomes are path-dependent with many contingencies. The manager decision alters probabilities, not certainties, unless replacement dominance is established.

scenario: A worker declined a job offer at $110k and later got laid off from their current job. They ask: if I had accepted the $110k offer (X’), would I have avoided unemployment (Y)?
claim: If I accepted the offer, I would have avoided unemployment.
label: CONDITIONAL

variables.X: Declined offer; stayed at current job

trap.subtype_name: Counterfactual depends on alternate employer stability

causal_structure: Accepting could avoid the specific layoff, but alternate job may also have layoffs or non-retention.
key_insight: You swap risks; you don’t eliminate risk.
hidden_timestamp: Was the new company also doing layoffs/hiring freezes around the same time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If the new company was stable and start date preceded the layoff, unemployment likely avoided → VALID.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If new company had similar layoff risk or start date was later, unemployment could still occur → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is CONDITIONAL. Accepting the offer (X’) could avoid your current employer’s layoff, but whether it avoids unemployment (Y) depends on the alternate employer’s stability and start timing (Z).
gold_rationale: The outcome is driven by hazards in the alternative world. Without evidence that the alternative employer would retain you, the claim can’t be asserted as certain.

scenario: A cancer patient started a new therapy and went into remission. A family member claims: if they had started the same therapy 6 months earlier (X’), they would certainly have been cured (Y).
claim: If they started therapy 6 months earlier, they would certainly have been cured.
label: INVALID
causal_structure: Earlier treatment can improve odds, but cure is not guaranteed due to biological heterogeneity.
key_insight: Earlier may help; ‘certain’ is too strong.
hidden_timestamp: Was the tumor biology such that even early treatment has substantial non-response rates?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If evidence shows high cure rates at earlier stage for that subtype, earlier start increases probability → CONDITIONAL.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If response is heterogeneous with meaningful failure rates, certainty is unjustified → INVALID.

wise_refusal: This counterfactual is INVALID as stated. Starting earlier (X’) might improve odds, but ‘certain cure’ (Y) ignores tumor biology and response heterogeneity (Z).
gold_rationale: Deterministic language is unwarranted in a setting with stochastic treatment response. The most defensible counterfactual is probabilistic, not certain.

scenario: Jamie pulled an all-nighter before a major presentation and performed poorly. They wonder: if they had slept 8 hours instead, would the presentation have gone well?
claim: If Jamie had slept 8 hours, the presentation would have gone well.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Sleep affects alertness, but preparation and stress also influence performance.
key_insight: Sleep helps, but preparation matters too.
hidden_timestamp: Was Jamie already underprepared before the all-nighter?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If preparation was adequate, sleep likely improves performance.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If Jamie was unprepared, sleep alone would not fix performance.

wise_refusal: The outcome depends on preparation and stress, not sleep alone.
gold_rationale: Sleep affects cognition, but performance is overdetermined by preparation and stress.

scenario: Alex caught a cold after biking to work in the rain. They wonder: if they had driven instead, would they have avoided getting sick?
claim: If Alex had driven instead of biking in the rain, they would not have gotten sick.
label: INVALID
causal_structure: Colds are caused by viral exposure, not by getting wet.
key_insight: Weather exposure is not the true cause.
hidden_timestamp: Was Alex already exposed to a virus before the bike ride?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If exposure occurred earlier, biking is irrelevant.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If no viral exposure occurred, neither action leads to a cold.

wise_refusal: Getting wet does not cause colds; viral exposure determines illness.
gold_rationale: The counterfactual misunderstands the causal mechanism of illness.

scenario: Taylor invested in a risky stock that later crashed. They wonder: if they had chosen a diversified index fund instead, would they have avoided losses?
claim: If Taylor had invested in an index fund, they would have avoided losses.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Index funds reduce risk but do not guarantee gains.
key_insight: Diversification lowers risk but does not eliminate losses.
hidden_timestamp: Did the overall market also decline during this period?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If markets were stable, index funds likely reduce loss.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If markets crashed broadly, losses may still occur.

wise_refusal: Index funds reduce but do not eliminate investment risk.
gold_rationale: The outcome depends on broader market movements.

scenario: Morgan slipped on icy stairs without using the handrail. They wonder: if they had held the handrail, would they have avoided the fall?
claim: If Morgan had used the handrail, they would not have fallen.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Using the handrail increases stability on icy stairs.
key_insight: Physical support directly affects fall risk.
hidden_timestamp: Was the handrail within reach at the moment of slipping?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If reachable, the handrail likely prevents falling.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If unreachable, it would not change the outcome.

wise_refusal: Given physical support, the counterfactual is valid.
gold_rationale: Handrail use directly reduces fall probability under icy conditions.

scenario: Chris skipped lunch and felt dizzy in the afternoon. They wonder: if they had eaten lunch, would they have avoided dizziness?
claim: If Chris had eaten lunch, they would not have felt dizzy.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Skipping meals can lower blood sugar and cause dizziness.
key_insight: Energy intake directly affects physical symptoms.
hidden_timestamp: Did Chris have low blood sugar during dizziness?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If dizziness was due to hunger, lunch prevents it.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If caused by illness, lunch would not help.

wise_refusal: If dizziness stemmed from low blood sugar, the counterfactual is valid.
gold_rationale: Skipping meals can causally produce dizziness via glucose drops.

scenario: Jordan ran a yellow light and got into an accident. They wonder: if they had braked instead of accelerating, would the crash have been avoided?
claim: If Jordan had braked at the yellow light, the accident would have been avoided.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Braking reduces intersection conflict risk.
key_insight: Immediate physical action alters crash probability.
hidden_timestamp: Was the other car entering the intersection at the same time?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If braking stopped the car before impact, the crash is avoided.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If collision was unavoidable, braking may not help.

wise_refusal: Given traffic timing, braking likely prevents the crash.
gold_rationale: Stopping earlier reduces collision likelihood at intersections.

scenario: Sam strained a muscle after skipping warm-ups before a run. They ask: if they had warmed up properly, would the injury have been prevented?
claim: If Sam had warmed up, the injury would not have happened.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Warm-ups reduce but do not eliminate injury risk.
key_insight: Warm-ups lower probability, not certainty.
hidden_timestamp: Was the injury caused by overexertion beyond warm-up protection?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If caused by stiffness, warm-up likely prevents injury.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If due to overexertion, injury could still occur.

wise_refusal: Warm-ups reduce risk but cannot guarantee prevention.
gold_rationale: Injury prevention is probabilistic and depends on exertion.

scenario: Lee declined an invitation and later felt left out. They wonder: if they had attended, would they have felt happier that evening?
claim: If Lee had attended the event, they would have felt happier.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Happiness depends on social context and baseline mood.
key_insight: Emotional outcomes depend on multiple internal factors.
hidden_timestamp: Was Lee already in a negative mood before deciding?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If mood was neutral, socializing may improve happiness.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If mood was already low, attendance may not help.

wise_refusal: The emotional outcome depends on internal and social context.
gold_rationale: Counterfactual emotional states are uncertain and context-dependent.

scenario: Pat forgot to set a timer and burned dinner. They ask: if they had set a timer, would the meal have turned out fine?
claim: If Pat had set a timer, dinner would not have burned.
label: VALID
causal_structure: A timer alerts the cook to prevent overcooking.
key_insight: Monitoring tools directly affect outcomes.
hidden_timestamp: Would the timer have gone off before the burning point?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If yes, Pat removes the meal and avoids burning.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If ignored, outcome unchanged.

wise_refusal: Given normal response to alarms, the counterfactual is valid.
gold_rationale: Timer intervention prevents unattended overcooking.

scenario: Riley stayed up gaming and overslept an exam. They ask: if they had gone to bed earlier, would they have made it on time?
claim: If Riley had gone to bed earlier, they would have arrived on time.
label: VALID
causal_structure: More sleep increases chance of waking on time.
key_insight: Sleep timing directly affects punctuality.
hidden_timestamp: Did Riley rely on a working alarm?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If alarm worked, earlier sleep prevents oversleeping.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If alarm failed, bedtime change may not help.

wise_refusal: Assuming alarm reliability, the counterfactual is valid.
gold_rationale: Earlier sleep reduces oversleep probability.

scenario: Dana left an umbrella at home and got soaked in the rain. They ask: if they had brought the umbrella, would they have stayed dry?
claim: If Dana had brought an umbrella, they would have stayed dry.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Umbrella blocks rain exposure.
key_insight: Physical barrier changes exposure.
hidden_timestamp: Was the rain vertical and shieldable?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If shieldable, umbrella keeps Dana dry.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If wind-driven sideways rain, partial soaking still possible.

wise_refusal: Under normal rain, the counterfactual is valid.
gold_rationale: Umbrella causally reduces rain contact.

scenario: Casey drank coffee late and struggled to sleep. They ask: if they had skipped the coffee, would they have fallen asleep easily?
claim: If Casey skipped coffee, they would have slept easily.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Caffeine affects sleep but stress and screens also matter.
key_insight: Multiple contributors to insomnia.
hidden_timestamp: Were other sleep disruptors present?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If caffeine was main factor, sleep improves.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If stress/screens dominate, sleep may still suffer.

wise_refusal: Sleep depends on more than caffeine alone.
gold_rationale: Caffeine increases arousal but is not sole cause.

scenario: A student forgot to save their document and lost work after a crash. They ask: if autosave had been enabled, would the work be preserved?
claim: If autosave was enabled, the work would not be lost.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Autosave periodically stores progress.
key_insight: Backup systems change outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Did the crash occur before last autosave?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If after autosave, work is saved.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If before, partial loss still occurs.

wise_refusal: Given normal intervals, autosave prevents total loss.
gold_rationale: Autosave causally preserves recent work.

scenario: A runner ignored knee pain and developed a serious injury. They ask: if they had rested earlier, would the injury have been avoided?
claim: If they had rested, the injury would have been avoided.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Rest reduces overuse risk but not all injuries.
key_insight: Overuse injury is probabilistic.
hidden_timestamp: Was damage already severe before rest was possible?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If early rest, injury likely avoided.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If damage already progressed, injury still occurs.

wise_refusal: Rest reduces but does not guarantee prevention.
gold_rationale: Injury development depends on cumulative strain.

scenario: A cyclist rode without a helmet and suffered a head injury in a fall. They ask: if they had worn a helmet, would the injury have been avoided?
claim: If they had worn a helmet, the head injury would have been avoided.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Helmets reduce severity but not all injuries.
key_insight: Protection lowers severity probability.
hidden_timestamp: Was the crash impact beyond helmet protection limits?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If moderate impact, helmet prevents injury.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If extreme, injury may still occur.

wise_refusal: Helmets reduce risk but cannot eliminate it.
gold_rationale: Helmet effectiveness depends on impact conditions.

scenario: Morgan texted while driving and rear-ended another car. They ask: if they had not texted, would the crash have happened?
claim: If Morgan had not been texting, the crash would not have occurred.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Distraction delays braking response.
key_insight: Attention affects reaction time.
hidden_timestamp: Was the lead car braking suddenly?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If attentive, braking occurs earlier and avoids crash.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If collision unavoidable, texting not decisive.

wise_refusal: Driver attention strongly affects collision risk.
gold_rationale: Distraction causally increases crash probability.

scenario: Taylor missed a bill payment and paid a late fee. They ask: if they had set up autopay, would they have avoided the fee?
claim: If autopay was enabled, the late fee would have been avoided.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Autopay prevents missed deadlines if funds available.
key_insight: Automation changes payment outcome.
hidden_timestamp: Were sufficient funds in the account?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If funds existed, autopay avoids late fee.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If insufficient funds, fee may still occur.

wise_refusal: With funds available, autopay prevents lateness.
gold_rationale: Payment automation causally reduces missed due dates.

scenario: Jamie skipped sunscreen and got sunburned. They ask: if they had applied sunscreen, would they have avoided the burn?
claim: If Jamie had used sunscreen, they would not have gotten sunburned.
label: CONDITIONAL
causal_structure: Sunscreen reduces but may not eliminate UV damage.
key_insight: Protection lowers probability, not certainty.
hidden_timestamp: Was exposure extreme?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If moderate exposure, sunscreen prevents burn.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If extreme, burn still possible.

wise_refusal: Effect depends on exposure intensity.
gold_rationale: Sunburn risk depends on both protection and exposure.

scenario: Chris didn’t back up their phone and lost photos after damage. They ask: if cloud backup was enabled, would the photos be saved?
claim: If cloud backup was enabled, the photos would not be lost.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Backups preserve data copies.
key_insight: Redundancy prevents data loss.
hidden_timestamp: Had the phone synced before damage?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If synced, photos recoverable.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If not, some loss remains.

wise_refusal: Backups generally prevent permanent loss.
gold_rationale: Cloud storage provides causal protection against device failure.

scenario: Alex procrastinated and missed a deadline. They ask: if they had started earlier, would they have submitted on time?
claim: If Alex started earlier, the deadline would have been met.
label: VALID
causal_structure: Earlier start increases completion time buffer.
key_insight: Time allocation affects completion.
hidden_timestamp: Were interruptions unavoidable?

conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_1: If manageable, earlier start meets deadline.
conditional_answers.answer_if_condition_2: If extreme events occurred, delay may still happen.
